title: Nationals’ bullpen buckles and playoff race tightens after 10-1 loss to Braves
text:
The Washington Nationals needed to protect a fragile lead, so they went to the bullpen. The starter, rookie right-hander Austin Voth, departed the mound in the sixth inning Saturday afternoon having so thoroughly baffled the Atlanta Braves that fans at Nationals Park gave him a standing ovation. But slowly at first and then all at once, everything fell apart.

Wander Suero gave up back-to-back singles and the one-run lead. Then, because Manager Dave Martinez thought his bullpen was taxed, Suero returned to start the seventh. He struggled to locate his pitches and walked the first two hitters before Martinez came to get him.

“He’s got to go back out,” the manager said. “[But] he just couldn’t throw strikes. He couldn’t locate his cutter. The walks, as we all know, when you walk in this league, you’re going to pay the price.”

Fernando Rodney fared no better. By the time the seventh inning ended eight batters later — after a frightening beaning, an ejection and a meltdown reminiscent of April and May — the Braves had built a lead they would never relinquish in a 10-1 victory that clinched their spot in the postseason for the second straight year.

The Nationals’ bullpen, by the time it was all over, registered just one more out (10) than runs allowed (nine). The implosion led to their eighth defeat in 12 games and made it easy to forget how much reconstruction they had done to avoid blowups such as these. The solace for those early-season collapses was time — something in short supply with 15 games left.

The defeat came shortly after the Chicago Cubs won another blowout and sliced the Nationals’ lead for the top NL wild-card spot to 1½ games, and the Milwaukee Brewers sit just a game behind the Cubs. The heightened stakes are apparent from Nationals Park, where the crowds for the first two games of this series have been larger and louder than they have been much of the season. The ballpark — and the tightening of the race — is not lost upon the Nationals.

“We’re at a point in the season where every game is kind of a must-win game,” reliever Sean Doolittle said. “Even [Friday night] there was a definite playoff vibe in the stadium.”

[Boswell: The Nats’ bullpen will be better in October — if they make it that far]

Rodney’s outing soured from the first pitch. He threw a 91-mph two-seam fastball that ran up and in to Charlie Culberson, hitting the pinch hitter in the face. Culberson remained on the ground for several minutes, surrounded by three trainers, before he departed on a medical cart holding a bloody towel over his right eye and cheek.

Rodney looked visibly affected by the moment, but Martinez stayed with him. “He seemed okay,” Martinez said.

Rodney was not available after the game. Braves Manager Brian Snitker said Culberson was awake and alert while being examined at a hospital Saturday night and that the pitch “missed the eye socket.”

“I know Rodney feels awful,” Martinez said.

While Culberson was on the ground, plate umpire Tim Timmons said Martinez asked him to review whether Culberson offered at the pitch. Timmons spoke with first base umpire Bill Welke, who said Culberson did.

“We’re always sympathetic to a guy hit in the eye,” Timmons explained. “But the rules are the rules.”

When Snitker realized what he thought would be a pinch runner actually would be a pinch hitter, he became apoplectic. The manager argued until Welke ejected him. The team on the field did not slow.

Ronald Acuña Jr. doubled down the left field line to give the Braves the lead. Ozzie Albies tried to check his swing, but the ball glanced off his bat and landed in almost the same spot as Acuña’s — another run-scoring double. The Nationals didn’t want to pitch to Freddie Freeman, so they intentionally walked him and got beat by another left-handed hitter, Nick Markakis, who singled in the Braves’ last run.

How the seventh inning further unraveled again laid bare the Nationals’ desperate need for a left-handed specialist with Roenis Elías’s timeline to return unclear and Martinez’s preference to save Doolittle for the highest-leverage situations.

The bullpen didn’t need to combust to assure the Nationals’ loss. Suero’s early hiccup would have been enough. The Nationals have scratched across one run in the first 18 innings of this series, and that came in the first after Trea Turner walked, advanced on a groundout and flew home on a double. The bats otherwise struggled to spark anything against Braves starter Mike Foltynewicz, who at one point retired 11 in a row.

“We scored one run in two games,” Martinez said, as if he could barely believe it. “We got to start hitting. We got to hit again. We’re swinging the bats, just not getting any hits, not creating anything offensively right now. We just got to regroup.”

Voth, for a while, looked as if he could maintain pace. He found an electric mix of the four-seam fastball, change-up, curveball and slide. He got 20 swings-and-misses in 80 pitches — a number only surpassed this season by the Nationals’ big three starters, though each of them only did it after throwing more than 100 total pitches. Even when he tired, and the Braves started to make more consistent contact, the defense helped with highlight-worthy plays from catcher Raudy Read, first baseman Ryan Zimmerman and center fielder Victor Robles.

Yet they and the rest of the defense could do nothing as the ball flew all over and out of reach for the rest of the night. The Nationals could not hold a slim lead on the field Saturday. The question now is whether they can hold one in the standings.
description: After a strong start from Austin Voth, relievers combine to yield nine runs.
authors: Sam Fortier Is A Sports Reporter For The Washington Post.
